Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: The passenger emergency alarm has been activated due to a medical emergency in the train.
Story: I was sitting in the break room, my uniform crisp and my radio clipped to my belt, when my phone buzzed. It was my mother, her voice trembling as she told me about Dad’s health scare last night. She needed me—her son—to listen, to reassure her, to be present. I could hear the fear in her words, the way she paused, waiting for me to say something comforting. But just as I opened my mouth, my radio crackled to life: “Operator, emergency alarm activated in car three. Possible medical emergency. Please respond immediately.” My heart pounded. I was needed on the train, responsible for the safety of dozens of passengers. I glanced at my phone, my mother’s voice still in my ear, desperate for support. At the same time, the weight of my duty as a subway operator pressed down on me. I felt torn in two, caught between the son my parents needed and the operator my passengers depended on, each role demanding my full attention, each impossible to ignore.
